author: By Katya Kazakina
title: What Will Become of a Tycoon’s Art Gems?
description: It’s the art world’s new guessing game: Will Sheldon Solow’s paintings and sculptures, conservatively valued at $500 million, be heading to a private museum or to auction?
content: In an apartment high above Manhattan, paintings by van Gogh, Matisse and Modigliani overlooked the East River and tribal artworks and Egyptian antiquities mingled with Giacometti bronzes and furniture. Several blocks west, a monumental Miró bronze stood guard by a skyscraper known for its sloping glass facade and masterpieces inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Coronavirus, Stimulus, Winter Solstice: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: We’ve Been Hacked
description: A sophisticated cyberattack breached multiple government agencies and major private companies, and no one noticed for months.
content: It’s going to be another bizarre holiday week. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech for the days ahead, and stay safe. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Qasim
title: What Books Should Biden Read? We Asked 22 Writers
description: George Will, Min Jin Lee, David Frum, Van Jones and others offer their recommendations to the president-elect.
content: On Jan. 20, Joseph R. Biden Jr. will be sworn into office as the 46th president of the United States. From that day forward, he will face countless challenges, including a divided nation, a global pandemic and an increasingly uncertain future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Ariana Grande Announces Engagement to Dalton Gomez
description: The pop star shared the news of her engagement to the Los Angeles real estate agent on Instagram, writing, “forever n then some.”
content: The pop star Ariana Grande is engaged to the luxury real estate agent Dalton Gomez, she announced on Instagram on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 20, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 20, 2020.
content: The Scene City article last Sunday misstated the length of time that humans are thought to have lived in the caves in Cantabria, Spain. Human existence goes back 300,000 years in the cave, not 300.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Apple closes all California stores as virus cases spike.
description: Apple is shuttering all 53 of its stores in California, as well as more than a dozen stores across Tennessee, Brazil, Mexico and the United Kingdom, because of a surge of coronavirus cases in those places, the company said.
content: Apple is shuttering all 53 of its stores in California, as well as more than a dozen stores across Tennessee, Brazil, Mexico and the United Kingdom, because of a surge of coronavirus cases in those places, the company said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: ‘Challenges and Bumps’ Expected as N.B.A. Returns
description: Playing without a bubble during the coronavirus pandemic hasn’t been smooth for sports leagues that tried this fall. Now it’s the N.B.A.’s turn.
content: On Tuesday night at Barclays Center, Stephen Curry will take the floor for the Golden State Warriors and Steve Kerr will coach the team in its first meaningful game in more than nine months. The considerable wait to get back to work is where the details only begin to take on layers for Kerr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey and Lucy Tompkins
title: The official leading Operation Warp Speed pins the blame for vaccine shortfalls on an administrative error.
description: After days of confusion about the uneven pace of vaccine distribution in the United States, a top official involved in the effort said on Sunday said that an administrative snafu was responsible for states being unable to order the number of doses promised to them for the coming week.
content: After days of confusion about the uneven pace of vaccine distribution in the United States, a top official involved in the effort said on Sunday said that an administrative snafu was responsible for states being unable to order the number of doses promised to them for the coming week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Morris
title: Feeling Socially Awkward? Even Extroverts Are a Little Rusty
description: Months of limited mingling has made even extremely outgoing people uncomfortable socializing, “like awkward eighth graders attending a school dance for the first time.”
content: Cece Cord, a loquacious socialite and designer, hosted a small luncheon over the summer graced with flowers from the garden at her hillside cottage in Millbrook, N.Y. But when the guests arrived, her social game was a little off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Christmas Without Music? Churches Are Finding a Way
description: At churches like St. James in Louisville, Ky., services this Christmas will not have in-person choirs or orchestras. But music directors are finding ways to persevere.
content: In a normal year, Phil Hines takes a deep breath, lays his hands on the keys of the 135-year-old pipe organ and begins to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: ‘The Pandemic Is a Prisoner’s Dilemma Game’
description: Using game theory, researchers modeled two ways of prioritizing vaccinations, to see which saved more lives.
content: Madhur Anand, an ecologist, and her husband, Chris Bauch, a mathematical biologist, were optimally situated during the spring lockdown, working from home in Guelph, Ontario, to watch the pandemic play out — and to discuss patterns of behavior, within their community and beyond, as we all tried to keep safe and carry on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Brinkmanship or Bluster? On Brexit and Pandemic, Boris Johnson Leaves It Late
description: Critics say the British prime minister’s penchant for last-minute decisions has complicated the handling of the coronavirus and narrowed the window for scrutiny of any trade deal with the E.U.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s 11th-hour reversal on a Christmas lockdown on Saturday so rattled Britain that it managed to overshadow the other down-to-the-wire drama he was staging: the trade negotiations in Brussels between his country and the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Alabama in Top Spot as College Football Playoff Is Set
description: The semifinals will be played on Jan. 1 in Louisiana and Texas, with the national championship scheduled for the Miami area on Jan. 11.
content: The coronavirus pandemic notwithstanding, the blue bloods are back in the College Football Playoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Devastated long-term care facilities become the next front for Covid-19 inoculations.
description: The rollout to nursing homes is beginning.
content: A large swath of nursing homes in the United States are poised to receive Covid-19 vaccines beginning Monday, as the country pushes to inoculate some of its most vulnerable citizens and free them from months of confinement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The coronavirus is mutating.
content: European countries began closing their borders to travelers from the United Kingdom a day after Prime Minister Boris Johnson ordered a lockdown on London and most of England’s southeast. The British leader said the restrictions were necessary to curb a new, faster-spreading variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 15 of the N.F.L. Season
description: The Chiefs won a potential Super Bowl preview against the Saints, the Titans and the Colts stayed hot and the previously winless Jets pulled off the upset of the season.
content: Favored teams did well on Sunday, with the Kansas City Chiefs beating the New Orleans Saints, the A.F.C. South heavyweights both winning and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers starting slowly before racing back for a surprising road win over Atlanta. But the previously winless Jets pulled off the upset of the season by beating the heavily favored Los Angeles Rams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: ‘Big Fight’ Breaks Out Over Which Interest Groups Get Vaccine First
description: Companies, unions and industry trade associations are lobbying governments to include their workers in the next round of virus vaccines.
content: The chief executive of Uber, the ride-hailing company whose six New York lobbying firms include Albany’s best connected, wrote last week to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo with an ask: priority for its drivers in the next round of coronavirus vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: A Conservative Justice in Wisconsin Says He Followed the Law, Not the Politics
description: Like officials in Arizona and Georgia, Justice Brian Hagedorn is a longtime Republican who is now under fire for ruling against President Trump’s challenges to the election.
content: Justice Brian Hagedorn of the Wisconsin Supreme Court is a veteran of the last decade’s fiercest partisan wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James J. Florio and Ouisie Shapiro
title: New York City vaccinated six million people in less than a month. In 1947.
description: In April 1947, New York City’s health commissioner, Israel Weinstein, had been on the job 10 months. He was a child on the Lower East Side when a smallpox outbreak brought the city to its knees in the early 1900s, killing 720 New Yorkers in a two-year period.
content: In April 1947, New York City’s health commissioner, Israel Weinstein, had been on the job 10 months. He was a child on the Lower East Side when a smallpox outbreak brought the city to its knees in the early 1900s, killing 720 New Yorkers in a two-year period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Ad Spending Soars in Georgia Races With Stakes Far Beyond Georgia
description: With control of the Senate up for grabs, the two Georgia runoff races have come to feel more like national elections than statewide ones.
content: The message from President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. that streamed across television screens in Georgia on Friday was simple, direct and dire: “Let me be clear: I need Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff in the United States Senate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Atherley
title: Pick Up the Knitting Needles for a Mood Booster
description: This inexpensive hobby abounds with benefits. And once you get good, you’ll be a mitten machine.
content: Already an excellent winter activity in an ordinary year, knitting is even better suited to 2020, when we’re being encouraged to stay home and restrict our social circles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: Giving Billions Fast, MacKenzie Scott Upends Philanthropy
description: Through a streamlined operation, Ms. Scott has given away $6 billion this year, much of it to small charities and nonprofits.
content: On a Monday evening in November, Dorri McWhorter, the chief executive of the Y.W.C.A. Metropolitan Chicago, got a phone call from a representative of the billionaire philanthropist MacKenzie Scott. The news was almost too good to be true: Her group would be receiving a $9 million gift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
title: Fight for Washington N.F.L. Team May Tighten Owner’s Grip on It
description: Washington’s owner, Daniel Snyder, is working to buy out three minority partners, including one he has accused of running a smear campaign against him.
content: By the end of this summer, Daniel Snyder, the majority owner of the N.F.L.’s Washington Football Team, was facing fire from many sides. Fans had long blamed him for the team’s abysmal performance. Now civil rights groups were criticizing Snyder for waiting so long to jettison a team name and logo that they considered racist, and women’s activists were aghast after news media reports detailed a culture of sexual harassment in the team’s front office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Coronavirus Is Mutating. What Does That Mean for Us?
description: Officials in Britain and South Africa claim new variants are more easily transmitted. There’s a lot more to the story, scientists say.
content: Just as vaccines begin to offer hope for a path out of the pandemic, officials in Britain this past weekend sounded an urgent alarm about what they called a highly contagious new variant of the coronavirus circulating in England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Pythons Slithered Through Europe Before Coiling Around the World
description: The oldest known fossils of the predatory snakes were found at a German site, changing the snake family tree.
content: From 20-foot anacondas to species that can comfortably fit on a quarter, snakes slither across much of the world today. That’s in part because they’re remarkably good at adapting to new environments — for instance, the Burmese python, native to Southeast Asia, is thriving in Florida’s Everglades National Park. Now, researchers have analyzed four fossilized python skeletons unearthed in Germany — part of a region that’s currently free of the scaly creatures — and rewritten the snake family trees.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Man Took My Bag and We Walked Around the Corner to His Cab’
description: A ride to Manhattan, looking skyward in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make vinegar chicken exactly as it’s written, or a speedy recipe for hummus.
content: Good morning. The next two weeks will be strange even by the standards of 2020, with the nation slowing into its annual end-of-year daydream, everyone taking stock of what happened and preparing for the new year, even as the fire hose of news continues to flow. Some will travel, no doubt. But many will simply hunker down to watch screens or read books or listen to music as we did in the early days of the pandemic, during the first lockdown, staying safe at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: You Don’t Have to Spend a Lot to Get Your Kids Outside
description: Many federal and state park systems offer inexpensive access for children and their families.
content: For kids (and really, all of us), there’s not a lot about this year that’s normal. One constant? That the great outdoors are just as great as ever. And many federal and state parks and organizations are working on expanding inexpensive access for kids and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Where Spiders Get Their Information
description: Sarah Keller and Derek Bowman are out to confuse us.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — We open our solving week with a collaboration between Sarah Keller and Derek Bowman, both veteran puzzle makers. They have worked together before, on at least two puzzles that ran in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Be Sleek and Silent’: How China Censored Bad News About Covid
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 20, 2020.
content: “China has a politically weaponized system of censorship; it is refined, organized, coordinated and supported by the state’s resources.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Emma Grillo
title: Celebrate Kwanzaa With a Craft Workshop and Take Some Time to Meditate
description: This week, stream Handel’s “Messiah,” listen to a conversation with Haim or check out virtual artwork from Judy Chicago.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Hospitals Are Still Short on Masks and Other Protective Gear
description: Health care workers are urging the incoming Biden administration to use the Defense Production Act to increase domestic manufacturing of personal protective equipment.
content: As Americans celebrate the rollout of a coronavirus vaccine, many of the doctors and nurses first in line for inoculation say a victory lap is premature. They fear that the optimism stirred by the vaccine will overshadow a crisis that has drawn scant public attention in recent months: the alarming shortage of personal protective equipment, or P.P.E., that has led frontline medical workers to ration their use of the disposable gloves, gowns and N95 respirator masks that reduce the spread of infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Fahim Abed
title: ‘Covid Can’t Compete.’ In a Place Mired in War, the Virus Is an Afterthought.
description: In Afghanistan, life goes on as though the coronavirus never existed. “Fake news,” some say, even as a second wave has brought on a surge of new cases and hospitalizations.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — For Mohammad Wakil, 23, social distancing is an abstract concept. Every working day, he shakes hands with scores of customers at the teeming bazaar where he sells secondhand shoes. He handles filthy Afghan bank notes. He disdains hand sanitizer. A mask? Forget about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Grace Knowlton, Sculptor Who Worked ‘in the Round,’ Dies at 88
description: A rare female modernist who broke into the masculine culture of outdoor sculpting, she exhibited her spheres at top museums and galleries.
content: Grace Knowlton, a sculptor who favored the elegance of the sphere, and who presented it in multiple materials and distended shapes and in sizes that ranged from the ornamental ball to an eight-foot boulder, died on Dec. 4 at a memory care facility in Old Tappan, N.J. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Nepal Falls Into Political Turmoil. China and India Are Watching.
description: The prime minister dissolved the lower house of Parliament, throwing into doubt the political fortunes of the Himalayan country, which has long swung between Beijing and New Delhi.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Nepal’s top leader dissolved Parliament on Sunday amid infighting among members of the governing party, throwing into doubt the political future of a strategically important Himalayan country where China and India have long jockeyed for influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: As vaccines arrive, the virus continues to ravage the U.S. and Europe.
description: As the coronavirus continues its surge across the United States and Europe, where vaccinations recently began, total infections around the world have now topped 75 million.
content: As the coronavirus continues its surge across the United States and Europe, where vaccinations recently began, total infections around the world have now topped 75 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Trump Incentives for Signing Peace Accords With Israel Could Be at Risk
description: Diplomatic sweeteners for joining the Abraham Accords that were offered to Morocco, Sudan and the United Arab Emirates could be rejected by Congress or reversed by the incoming Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — For Sudan, agreeing to normalize relations with Israel was the price of removal from the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: A President Who Can’t Put Aside Grudges, Even for Good News
description: The past week served as a preview of Mr. Trump’s post-presidency: no leadership on debates within his party, but keen attention to waging personal vendettas and cultivating his supporters.
content: It was among the most consequential weeks of President Trump’s tenure: Across the country, health care workers began receiving a lifesaving coronavirus vaccine. On Capitol Hill, lawmakers closed in on a deal for economic relief aimed at averting a deeper recession. And on Friday, federal regulators authorized a second vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Movement to Bring Death Closer’
description: America’s home-funeral guides want us to be less afraid and more in touch with death.
content: “If death practices reveal a culture’s values,” writes Maggie Jones, the author of today’s Sunday Read, “we choose convenience, outsourcing, an aversion to knowing or seeing too much.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Sunday Read Team
title: Best of The Sunday Read 2020: From Female Rage to Michelangelo’s David
description: A few of our favorite and most popular episodes of the narrated article series from “The Daily.”
content: For the past few months, The Sunday Read has been a fixture of the weekend feed on “The Daily,” featuring narrated renditions of The New York Times’s journalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Catie Lazarus, Comedian With a Lot of Questions, Dies at 44
description: On her live show “Employee of the Month,” she got laughs by interrogating writers, artists, politicians, intellectuals and her fellow comics.
content: Catie Lazarus, a writer and comedian who probed the minds of celebrities and created her own late-night comedy universe on her longstanding self-produced live New York talk show, “Employee of the Month,” died on Dec. 13 in her apartment in Brooklyn. She was 44.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jeanna Smialek
title: Lawmakers Resolve Fed Dispute as They Race to Close Stimulus Deal
description: Top senators appeared to strike an agreement on the central bank’s lending powers as they struggled to clear away the last sticking points in the $900 billion compromise plan.
content: WASHINGTON — Senators broke through an impasse late Saturday night over a Republican effort to curtail the powers of the Federal Reserve, clearing away what had been seen as the final hurdle to a deal on a $900 billion stimulus package as lawmakers raced against a Sunday-night deadline to avoid a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Stanley Cowell, Jazz Pianist With a Wide Range, Dies at 79
description: His playing consolidated generations of musical history. He was also a composer, an educator and the founder of an important artist-run record label.
content: Stanley Cowell, a pianist, composer, record-label impresario and educator who brought a technician’s attention to detail and a theorist’s sophistication to his more than 50-year career as a jazz bandleader, died on Friday in Dover, Del. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu becomes the first Israeli to be inoculated against Covid-19.
description: Arriving at the hospital wearing a short-sleeved polo shirt under his jacket, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu became the first Israeli to be inoculated against Covid-19 on Saturday night, saying he wanted to set an example and encourage all Israelis to get the vaccine.
content: Arriving at the hospital wearing a short-sleeved polo shirt under his jacket, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu became the first Israeli to be inoculated against Covid-19 on Saturday night, saying he wanted to set an example and encourage all Israelis to get the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: A Minnesota state senator, one of several who contracted the coronavirus after local Republican meetings, has died.
description: A Republican state senator from Minnesota who tested positive for the coronavirus last month has died, his wife said in a written statement.
content: A Republican state senator from Minnesota who tested positive for the coronavirus last month has died, his wife said in a written statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress Strikes Long-Sought Stimulus Deal to Provide $900 Billion in Aid
description: Democrats and Republicans said they had an agreement on another round of pandemic aid, including direct payments to Americans, jobless benefits and funds for businesses and vaccine distribution.
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders on Sunday reached a hard-fought agreement on a $900 billion stimulus package that would send immediate aid to Americans and businesses to help them cope with the economic devastation of the pandemic and fund the distribution of vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough and Jan Hoffman
title: Frontline Workers and People Over 74 Should Get Shots Next, C.D.C. Panel Says
description: The recommendation was a compromise aimed at getting the coronavirus vaccine to the most vulnerable of two high-risk groups.
content: Striking a compromise between two high-risk population groups, a panel advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention voted Sunday to recommend that people age 75 and older be next in line to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the United States, along with about 30 million “frontline essential workers,” such as emergency responders, teachers and grocery store employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cathy Park Hong
title: How Fake News Is Hatching in Immigrant Communities
description: Right-wing conspiracy theories are reaching Asian and Latino voters through platforms like WeChat, KakaoTalk and WhatsApp. Democrats must take notice.
content: In August I was on the phone with my mother, a 70-year-old Korean immigrant, to discuss the upcoming election. In the past, she had complained that President Trump was a lunatic, so I naturally assumed that she would support — or at least be neutral about — Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Finds a New Joe Biden After Jim Carrey Exits
description: Alex Moffat became the latest “S.N.L.” cast member to portray Biden, following Carrey’s announcement that he was stepping down from the role.
content: It was with some fanfare that “Saturday Night Live” announced in the fall that it had recruited Jim Carrey to play former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., then the Democratic presidential nominee and now president-elect. At the time, Lorne Michaels, the “S.N.L.” creator and executive producer, went so far as to say that Carrey’s performance would be “stunning and possibly transcend comedy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: United Sends a Message. But What Kind, Exactly?
description: A 6-2 thumping of Leeds moved United into third place in the Premier League. But a single day never tells the whole story of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s team.
content: MANCHESTER, England — The fourth goal, the one that signaled a victory turning into a rout, was the one that meant the most. Manchester United’s coaching staff poured from the bench. On the sideline, several of the handful of stewards standing guard over Old Trafford’s empty stands celebrated wildly. And on the field, the players grinned and roared and beamed from ear to ear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: A Company Made P.P.E. for the World. Now Its Workers Have the Virus.
description: Top Glove, the world’s largest rubber glove maker, has enjoyed record profits in the pandemic, even as thousands of its low-paid workers in Malaysia suffer from a large outbreak of Covid-19.
content: BANGKOK — Day after day, as the pandemic gathered force, Yam Narayan Chaudhary stood sentry for 13.5-hour shifts at Top Glove, the Malaysian company that is the world’s largest disposable glove maker. Thousands of foreign workers, many from Nepal like Mr. Chaudhary, lined up as he checked their temperatures and waved them through to the factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: The Antitrust Case Against Big Tech, Shaped by Tech Industry Exiles
description: Regulators are relying on insiders like Dina Srinivasan, who left her digital ad job after concluding that “Facebook and Google were going to win and everybody else is going to lose.”
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Three years ago, before she became an antitrust scholar whose work laid the blueprint for a new wave of monopoly lawsuits against Big Tech, Dina Srinivasan was a digital advertising executive bored with her job and worried about the bleak outlook for the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Tiger Woods Mixes Golf and Family Once Again
description: Normally Woods tries to keep his private life separate from his career, but playing with his son Charlie in the PNC Championship was an emotional father-son bonding moment.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — As he does with the accessories in his golf bag, Tiger Woods neatly arranges his life in tidy compartments. His life as a high-profile golfer goes in one slot, his family goes in another and, like his favored chunky peanut butter and banana sandwiches and the rest of his luggage, he’d prefer to keep it all separated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘U.S. and States Say Facebook Illegally Crushed Competition’
description: In this lesson, students will learn why U.S. regulators are seeking to break up the social networking giant — and consider what this means for us and Big Tech.
content: Featured Article: “U.S. and States Say Facebook Illegally Crushed Competition” by Cecilia Kang and Mike Isaac
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai, Apoorva Mandavilli and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Countries begin barring travelers from the U.K. over concerns of a new coronavirus variant.
description: Countries across Europe and beyond began closing their borders to travelers from the United Kingdom on Sunday, and the European Union set up a crisis management meeting, a day after Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, ordered a wholesale lockdown on London and surrounding areas, citing concerns of a new fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus.
content: Countries across Europe and beyond began closing their borders to travelers from the United Kingdom on Sunday, and the European Union set up a crisis management meeting, a day after Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, ordered a wholesale lockdown on London and surrounding areas, citing concerns of a new fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Tyler Hicks
title: ‘I Miss Home’: In Tigray Conflict, Displaced Children Suffer
description: Of the thousands of refugees who have fled the conflict in the northern Ethiopian region of Tigray, nearly a third are children. Hundreds of them walked unaccompanied to Sudan.
content: UM RAKUBA, Sudan — The Um Rakuba refugee camp is filling again, stifling in the afternoon sun in eastern Sudan, and there are children everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A (Virtual) Walk Through New York History
description: The Times architecture critic Michael Kimmelman spent the past 10 months exploring the city’s communities with architects, writers and historians. Here’s what he learned.
content: When Michael Kimmelman, The Times’s architecture critic, embarked on his series of strolls through New York City in March, he knew he’d be providing a peek at Midtown’s skyscrapers and Harlem’s brownstones for readers around the world. But he also hoped New Yorkers would turn to the walks as a source of comfort and pride while they hunkered down at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon
title: Don’t Just Read the News, Build With It
description: Roll up your Sunday paper and create your own geodesic dome.
content: You’re barreling toward  cold, dark days filled with nothing to do, which means now is the perfect time to spend those hours building your own geodesic dome to hide — um, play  — in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: F.D.A. Wants to Stop Regulating French Dressing
description: The federal agency said it was seeking to revoke its definition for the carrot-colored dressing, effectively erasing a government-required list of ingredients at the request of an industry group.
content: In the grand pantheon of salad dressings, French dressing can be easily forgotten — a sticky, sweet, carrot-colored blend overshadowed by America’s undisputed heavyweight champion of dressings, ranch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: How We Survive Winter
description: The solstice arrives in the depths of the pandemic. But the season of darkness also offers ancient lessons of hope and renewal.
content: The solstice arrives in the depths of the pandemic. But the season of darkness also offers ancient lessons of hope and renewal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez, Josh Holder, Lauren Leatherby, Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Lucy Tompkins
title: As Christmas Nears, Virus Experts Look for Lessons From Thanksgiving
description: Public health experts warned that large holiday gatherings would spread the coronavirus broadly. Weeks later, the data is complicated.
content: Public health experts warned that large holiday gatherings would spread the coronavirus broadly. Weeks later, the data is complicated.
